notes: First generation Ford Escort on CE14 platform. Diesel option (2.0L Mazda RF) available 1984-1987 requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Turbocharged CVH engine in GT models requires boost system maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escort (North America) article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Ford Escort on CE14 platform with updated 1.9L engine introduced mid-1985. Diesel option (2.0L Mazda RF) available through 1987 requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Central Fuel Injection system introduced 1987. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escort (North America) article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact pickup on body-on-frame platform with Twin I-Beam front suspension. SuperCab extended cab introduced 1986. Diesel options include 2.2L Perkins (1983-1984) and 2.3L Mitsubishi turbo diesel (1985-1987), requiring diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Available in 6-foot and 7-foot bed lengths. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranger (North America) article, January 2025 revision.

Ninth generation aerodynamic Thunderbird on Fox platform. Turbo Coupe model features 2.3L turbocharged engine with intercooler added in 1987 (190 hp). First Thunderbird with 5-speed manual transmission option. Significant refresh in 1987 with new aerodynamic sheet metal and composite headlamps. Special editions include Elan (1984) and 30th Anniversary (1985). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Taurus on DN5 platform with revolutionary aerodynamic 'jelly bean' design. Launched 1985 as 1986 model, replacing Ford LTD mid-size car. HSC I4 engine available with 5-speed manual or 3-speed automatic. 3.8L Essex V6 added in 1988 as optional upgrade. Wheelbase 106.0 inches. Trim levels: MT-5 (manual), L (base), GL, and LX. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Taurus (first generation) article, January 2025 revision.

Compact sedan and coupe sharing components with Ford Escort but with 5.7-inch longer wheelbase. Optional AWD introduced 1987. Diesel option (2.0L Mazda RF) available 1984-1986 paired only with 5-speed manual, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Mercury twin badged as Topaz. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Tempo article, January 2025 revision.

First generation minivan on VN1 platform with 118.9-inch wheelbase. Marketed as 'first minivan powered exclusively by V6 engines' though 2.3L I4 available 1986-1987. 2.8L V6 only available first few months of 1986, 3.0L Vulcan became sole engine in 1988. Designed with focus on garageability and towing capacity. Trim levels: XL and XLT. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Aerostar article, January 2025 revision.

Compact SUV derived from Ford Ranger platform with 94.0-inch wheelbase. 1984-1985 models exclusively four-wheel drive with carbureted 2.8L V6. Three-door wagon body style only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco II article, January 2025 revision.

Compact SUV derived from Ford Ranger platform with 94.0-inch wheelbase. 1986+ models available with RWD or 4WD. Optional 2.3L Mitsubishi turbodiesel (1986-1987) had poor performance and low sales, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Upgraded to fuel-injected 2.9L V6 in 1986. Three-door wagon body style only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco II article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh generation full-size pickup. SuperCab returned in 1980, four-door crew cab introduced 1982. 3.8L V6 standard in 1982 (phased out 1983), 4.2L V8 phased out by 1982. 6.9L diesel V8 available for F-250/F-350 starting 1983, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Final generation with 3-speed manual transmission. 5.0L V8 gained fuel injection in 1986. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Eighth generation full-size pickup. 4.9L inline-six gained fuel injection in 1987. 5.8L V8 fuel injected starting 1988. Diesel engine upgraded from 6.9L to 7.3L, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). E4OD 4-speed automatic introduced 1989 for heavy-duty applications. All gasoline engines feature fuel injection. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Fox body Mustang (1979-1993). Convertible returned in 1983 after decade-long hiatus. 2.3L turbocharged engine gained fuel injection in 1983. 4.2L V8 (255 cu in) available 1980-1981 only. 5.0L V8 evolved from carbureted to Central Fuel Injection to Sequential Electronic Fuel Injection with power ranging from 139 hp to 225 hp. 3.8L Essex V6 introduced 1983. Various performance packages including GT. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (third generation) article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation full-size Bronco based on F-Series platform. Four-wheel drive standard with New Process 208 transfer case. Dana 44 front axle with Twin Traction Beam suspension. Ford 9-inch rear axle transitioning to 8.8 rear axle by 1986. Hardtop configuration with sliding window glass option prior to 1984. Trim levels: Bronco (base), Bronco XL, Bronco XLT. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Econoline full-size van with Twin-I-Beam front suspension and live rear axle with leaf springs. Available as cargo van, passenger van (Club Wagon), and cutaway chassis. Multiple engine options including large-displacement V8s for commercial applications. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Econoline full-size van with Twin-I-Beam front suspension and live rear axle with leaf springs. 6.9L International IDI diesel V8 introduced 1983 for E-350 models only, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Available as cargo van, passenger van (Club Wagon), and cutaway chassis. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Econoline full-size van with Twin-I-Beam front suspension and live rear axle with leaf springs. Diesel engine enlarged from 6.9L to 7.3L International IDI V8 in 1988, available for E-350 models only, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Available as cargo van, passenger van (Club Wagon), and cutaway chassis. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size sedan and wagon on rear-wheel drive Panther platform. Became stand-alone model line in 1983 after being premium trim of Ford LTD. 5.0L V8 upgraded to Sequential-Fire multiport fuel injection in 1986 (150 hp). Trim levels include Standard, LX (introduced 1986), and S (fleet/police oriented). Station wagon available with optional woodgrain trim. Police Package available with heavy-duty specifications. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford LTD Crown Victoria article, January 2025 revision.
